speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So the tightening cycle, as you know, is a reflection of the strength of the economy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And it’s almost three years now that we’ve been gradually raising rates.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And I think the fact that we have moved quite gradually, in a way, allows us to carefully watch incoming data in the real economy and in the financial markets to see how the economy is processing higher interest rates.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And the fact that we’re moving so gradually—I think it—I think it limits the long and variable lags problem because, you know, we’re being able to raise rates and then wait and see how the economy absorbs these rate increases.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And so far, the economy has performed very well and very much in keeping with our expectations.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So we’ve been given a really important job to do on behalf of the American people by Congress, and we’ve been given the tools to do it, and my colleagues September 26, 2018 and I are focused exclusively on carrying out that mission.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We consider the best thinking, the Chairman Powell’s Press Conference FINAL best theory, and the best evidence.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We have disparate points of view, which we debate extensively and come to a perspective and try to set monetary policy to achieve maximum employment in a context of price stability.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: That’s what we do.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We don’t consider political factors or things like that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And so that’s who we are, that’s what we do, and that’s just the way it’s always going to be for us.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Sure.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So in terms of financial markets and monetary policy, we—as we say in our statement every cycle, we do take financial conditions into consideration because financial—broader financial conditions do affect the broader economy, and they’re one of the many things that we take into account.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: The part of it that we control, though, is what we do with the federal funds rate and that has—that has effects out through, you know, out through the full interest rate curve and into financial asset prices generally.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So the answer is, we take everything into account, but, you know, broader financial conditions are just one of the things that we take into account.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So you’re right.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Some of—some of the participants have mostly very modest September 26, 2018 overshoots of their personal estimates of neutral a couple—three years out.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You know, it’s far Chairman Powell’s Press Conference FINAL out into the future.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I think it’s hard to be confident that that’s—that that’s the way things are going to be.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: What we’re going to be doing as we—as we go through time is asking at every meeting whether monetary policy is set to achieve our goals.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And I think that that’s an assessment of where policy will need to be some years down the road, and I’ll leave it at that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: No, you’re right.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: The Committee forecasts what they—what they show, in general, is an economy where unemployment remains in the high and middle 3s throughout the entire forecast period and inflation remains very close to 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: That is what the forecast shows.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And that is based on our understanding of the way the inflation process works now and on the fact that the inflation seems to be fairly nonreactive to changes in slack— that is to say, a flat Phillips curve.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And it’s just—it’s a—it’s a world of strongly anchored inflation expectations.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And that’s not just our forecast, that’s many forecasts.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So that is—that is —that is the forecast.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And so that really is a longer-run concept that we think the economy will return to over the longer run.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: But, obviously, that longer run, you know, isn’t— it’s not creating problems in the short run for that forecast.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Now let’s just admit that the inflation process has changed dramatically from where it was in the 1960s to where it is now.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: It’s in a good place now.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We can’t take for granted that it will remain the way it is, and, you know, we will be, of course, watching carefully.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: If inflation reacts more strongly or more weakly to the strong economy, then we’ll adjust policy appropriately.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: It would look very different, I think, if we didn’t raise rates.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We’re always trying to, you know, work our way between the—sort of the two—the two problems we face.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: One is that if we move too quickly, we can, you know, snuff out a recovery unnecessarily, and inflation falls short of its 2 percent target.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Or if we move too slowly, we have an economy that can overheat.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So we’re—that—that’s happened through history.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We don’t see any signs of that now, but we’re always trying to navigate between those two shoals.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And we think that gradually, you know, raising interest rates is the way that we kind of take both of those risks seriously.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So I think one of the most important lessons from the financial crisis is really the importance of the stability of the financial system.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And so we—since the financial crisis, as you’re aware, we’ve had a major focus on building up our monitoring of financial conditions and financial stability issues.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We’ve also put in place many, many initiatives to strengthen the financial system through higher capital and better regulation, more transparency, central clearing, margins on uncleared derivatives, all kinds of things like that, which are meant to strengthen the financial system.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We’ve done many of those things, and we feel that the financial system is in a much better place.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: As we look at—as we look at conditions most recently—and this was at our last meeting, and it was in our minutes for the last meeting—quarterly, we have a briefing at the FOMC, and also at the Board, of the staffs’ views on financial stability, and the staff judged the overall vulnerabilities to be moderate.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: If you dig into the different aspects of that question, households or balance sheets are in good shape.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You know, employment is high, wages are rising, that sort of thing.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: The banking system, as I mentioned, is—you know, much higher capital, much higher liquidity—is much stronger.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: If you look at asset prices, it is true that some asset prices are in the upper range of their historical—upper reach of their historical ranges.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And then if you look at nonfinancial corporates, you get—there is the story of leverage there.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So it’s not that there aren’t any vulnerabilities, but we see them as moderate.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Now, you ask about the countercyclical capital buffer.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: The countercyclical capital buffer is a tool that we added to our toolkit, I think, finally, back in 2016.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We said that we would deploy it when vulnerabilities were meaningfully above normal.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We revisit that on a regular schedule, and the last time we revisited it was, I think, last year—sometime last year—and concluded that the test was not met.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: As I mentioned at the last briefing, the—you know, the September 26, 2018 assessment was that vulnerabilities were moderate, but it remains a kit—a tool for our toolkit that Chairman Powell’s Press Conference FINAL we can deploy, you know, when and as we feel appropriate.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: As I said, I think I’m in the camp of seeing vulnerabilities as relatively moderate.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I think the financial system—I think another thing that we learned in the crisis is that we need to be alert to the buildup of vulnerabilities as a long expansion continues.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I don’t see that in troubling—troubling amounts at this point, but, you know, I think it’s appropriate for us to monitor that very carefully.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Sure.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So I guess I need to start by saying that we’re not responsible for trade policy, and we don’t comment on particular, you know, trade actions and that sort of thing.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: But you will have seen that we have this very extensive network of business contacts around the country through the Reserve Banks largely, and we’ve been hearing a rising chorus of concerns from businesses all over the country about disruption of supply chains, materials costs and increases, and loss of markets, and things like that.

sentence: So we’ve been hearing quite a lot of that, and we—the Reserve Bank presidents talk about it in the meeting, and it goes in the minutes.

sentence: So we, you know, that’s—we’re very transparent about hearing all that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I think if you look at the aggregate perform—the performance of the U.S. economy at an aggregate—at September 26, 2018 a national level, it’s hard to see much happening at this point.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And they’re still relatively small.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You know, we worry about a couple of things.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: One is loss of business confidence, which could reduce investment.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Again, we don’t really see effects that we could measure yet.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Also, the possibility of a financial market reaction over time to unexpected trade developments.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: More than anything, though, I would worry, in the longer run, where this is going, you know.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: If the— if the end place we get to is lower tariffs, that would be good, you know.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Trade generally supports productivity, supports higher incomes.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And, you know, fair trade—fair trade under internationally accepted rules can be a good thing.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I think if this, perhaps inadvertently, goes to a place where we have widespread tariffs that remain in place for a long time—a more protectionist world—that’s going to be bad for the United States’ economy and for American workers, and families, and also for other economies.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So it’s true.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: This year has—we’ve kept raising our forecast for this year.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: This—as the year’s gone on, the economy has come in stronger than we expected, and that’s a really good thing.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And the economy, as I mentioned at the beginning, is strong, and there’s good reason to expect that to continue.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You ask why.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You know, some of it is, no doubt, the effect of the fiscal policy changes, the tax cuts, and the spending increases—that’s got to be part of the story.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: But, you know, the growth picture is very much supported by very high readings of Chairman Powell’s Press Conference FINAL household confidence, business confidence, so it’s a—it’s a—it’s a—it’s a pretty particularly bright moment, I think.

sentence: If you look back over the last decade, this is a pretty good moment for the U.S. economy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL

sentence: So, you know, we hope they’re huge, frankly.

sentence: You know, the idea is, you cut—you reduce taxation on corporations and particularly—and allow faster expensing for investment.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So the effects are very uncertain, they’re—you know, they’re—the literature is—it’s—there’s no clear answer to exactly how these mechanisms work or how effective they are.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And it would be soon to be seeing supply-side effects.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: The other—supply-side effects are probably both more uncertain and they’re probably slower to come in.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: But, you know, as I said, we—I certainly hope—I hope that we’ll be marking up our estimates of potential growth as well.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Okay, so I think I mentioned in the opening remarks maybe something that addressed your question about what would make us go faster and slower.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You know, the main thing where we might need to move along a little bit quicker would be if inflation—inflation surprises to the upside.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We don’t see that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We really don’t see that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: It’s not in our forecast, but any—so I would—I regard that as a risk.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I think either a significant— significant—correction and lasting correction in financial markets or a slowing down in the economy that’s inconsistent with our forecast—those are the kinds of things we’d react to.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: In terms of what, you know, what we would do—you know, I think we’re always going to be adjusting monetary policy to—in light of conditions on the ground.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So if the economy is weakening, then it’s very possible we’d be—we’d be cutting rates and, you know, vice versa.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And so I can’t rule that out.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: It—I think it’s quite difficult, though, to know what the effects— what the sort of end effects of fiscal policy are going to be in 2020.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: It’s difficult to know what the policy will be, let alone what their effects will be that far out.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So we have to make estimates, but we know that they’re highly uncertain.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You know, so we’ve been—I think the perform—labor September 26, 2018 force participation has surprised us on the upside.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: If you look—if you look at labor force participation, since the fourth quarter of ’13 till now, you really have a—kind of an oscillation that basically is a sideways movement in the face of a significant downward trend, thanks to aging and other factors.

sentence: That’s a gain of well more than a percentage point in participation, so that’s really— that’s really a good thing.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And, you know, we don’t know how long it can continue.

sentence: We have models, and we look at this—we look at this question all the time.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And, you know, admittedly, we’ve been surprised on the positive side here, so we’re open to the idea that that may continue or not.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: It’s a concern.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: It’s a risk.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You know, so you could see prices moving up.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You don’t see it yet, but we—you could see retail prices moving up.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: The tariffs September 26, 2018 might provide a basis for companies to raise prices in a world where they’ve been very reluctant Chairman Powell’s Press Conference FINAL to and unable to raise prices, where raising prices is really difficult, you know, with the ability to shop on the internet.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: This could provide, you know, a way for—again, we don’t see it in the numbers.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And, you know, until we see it in the numbers, it’s hard to say how one would react.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And that’s a real—that’s an important question in, in how we would think about the appropriate response.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Don’t see it yet.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You know, don’t see it yet, but we—you’re hearing—I mean, broadly across the economy, it’s not just tariffs.

sentence: You’re hearing—we’re hearing a lot of talk of labor shortages, of material costs in particular industries.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We’re hearing a lot, you know, what amount to supply-side constraints and things like that, but we’re not seeing it.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We’re seeing a sort of modest increase in wages, inflation right around 2 percent, no sense of it moving up really, so we’re not seeing it yet.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: A couple questions in there.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So the dot plot—I mean, I—it’s not new.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I don’t think it’s a new point that forecasts two and three out—two or three years out are fairly uncertain.

sentence: The dot plot is individual FOMC participants who are writing down their individual views on the evolution of the economy and of appropriate monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: These are individual forecasts.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I think market participants generally find that interesting information, and so it seems to me to be serving a purpose.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I think the point with “accommodative” was that its useful life was over.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You know, we put that in the statement in 2015, just when we lifted off, and the idea was to provide assurance that we weren’t trying to slow down the economy, but, in fact, we were still—interest rates were still going to be pushing to support economic activity.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Well, that—you know, that purpose has been well served, and the language now doesn’t really say anything that’s important to the way the Committee is thinking about policy going forward.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Yeah, you know, it’s—if you look at a broad financial conditions index, that’s pretty much the answer you’ll get.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL

sentence: Okay, so in terms of nominations to the Fed, those are entirely, completely under the control of the White House and, ultimately, the President.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: But these are—these are really decisions for the White House, and, you know, we are—think of us as just being consulted.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I will say that I’m very happy and excited about the team that we’re putting together, and I’m very much looking forward to having those offices up and down our hall filled.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: It’s been pretty quiet, more quieter than usual, which is saying something on the Board hall.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So we’re looking forward to getting some people confirmed.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: In terms of corporate debt, so this is a—this is a—you know, I was an investor for a long time in areas that were very close to the leveraged lending markets.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So, you know, I have had a lot of experience in that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: That market has evolved really significantly since before the crisis.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And, you know, the banks take much less risk than they used to.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: They’re—the—they’re September 26, 2018 essentially in the business of distributing these loans and bonds rather than keeping them on their Chairman Powell’s Press Conference FINAL balance sheet, to a much greater degree.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: But it’s also true—and there’s significant research on this—that excessive risk-taking in the leveraged lending markets does have channels for affecting the real economy, if there’s overheating and that kind of thing in those markets, so we monitor that carefully.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You know, the guidance is—isn’t binding, as you pointed out, that the leveraged lending isn’t binding, and that’s just—that’s just the way that the law is interpreted.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So it’s something we’re monitoring, and, as I mentioned, we think overall vulnerabilities are moderate.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So I think if you look at the—look at the dot plot in the SEP, you’ll see that the federal funds rate, even after today’s move, is below the longer-run neutral estimate of every single participant that—who submits a— an estimate of that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So that’s why this is the perfect time to take the language out, because, you know, it’s perfectly clear that there can’t be a signal because, you know, by definition, that means an accommodative policy.

sentence: There’s another point, though, too, which is, you know, we don’t want to suggest either that we have this precise understanding of where “accommodative” stops or suggest that that’s a really important point in our thinking.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You know, what we’re going to be doing, assuming we September 26, 2018 stay on this path, is, we’re going to be carefully monitoring incoming data from the financial Chairman Powell’s Press Conference FINAL markets and from the economy and asking ourselves whether our policy is achieving the goals we want to achieve—you know, sustain the economy, maximum employment, stable prices.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: That’s the way we’re thinking about it, and that does kind of amount to thinking less about one’s precise point estimate of the neutral rate.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So that’s how I think about that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: It’s possible.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: It’s very possible.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: It happens often.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And, as I mentioned, many of the participants have written that down, and they’ve written down really modest overshoots, you know, amounting to one rate hike kind of thing, which wouldn’t have a big effect on the economy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You know, it—I would just say, you know, it really depends on what happens.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: It depends on if we keep going—you can think of it different ways.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So, three things there.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: The first thing is the single biggest thing I think that we learned was the—as I mentioned, I think, earlier, the importance of maintaining the stability of the financial system.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So we—you know, we put a tremendous focus on that.

sentence: We raised capital, liquidity.

sentence: We have stress tests, which force banks to understand—the largest banks particularly—to understand and better manage their risk and have enough capital to survive a really substantial shock that’s at least as bad as the financial crisis.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL

sentence: Nobody’s—you know, nobody is, I think, overconfident that we’ve solved every problem.

sentence: And, you know, now we’re going back and kind of taking a hard look at everything and, you know, trying to make—trying to—trying to keep at it.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So I think those are the really important lessons, and, you know, we—we’re determined not to, you know, not to forget them.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And that’s, I think, a risk now—is to—is to forget things that we—that we learned.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: That’s just human nature over time.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So there was sort of a trade for taking away our power under September 26, 2018 13, section 13(3), to provide support to individual nonbanks, which is really holding companies Chairman Powell’s Press Conference FINAL and other companies.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: In exchange for that, we got orderly liquidation authority and a resolution authority.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I don’t think there’s any sense that Congress would seriously look at changing that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I have real doubts about whether it was wise to take away our crisis-fighting tools.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I think you put them away, and you hope you never need them, but—and I certainly strongly oppose efforts to take away more of our tools.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You know, the third thing you mentioned is the designation power.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So it’s a really important power.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: In my mind, it should be used—my thinking, it should be used sparingly, and that means, you know, in situations where you have—I mean, in principle, you could have another Lehman Brothers come up out of the ground that’s not a bank, and it could be very threatening—or it could be capable of creating systemic risk.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And so I think it’s a critical power to have.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: But, again, I would use it—I would tend to use it fairly sparingly.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Yeah, we look—of course, we look at that very carefully, and interest rates are going up across a broad range of consumer borrowing, as they would when we raise short-term interest rates.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: They’re still quite low by historical levels.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And the other thing I’ll say is, take—if you take housing, if you look at the NAR Affordability Index, housing is still more affordable now than it was before the financial crisis.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So you’re right that the cost of borrowing is going up, but it’s going up from what were extraordinarily low levels, and it is September 26, 2018 something that we watch carefully.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You know, the effect on consumer spending is a very Chairman Powell’s Press Conference FINAL important channel through which interest rates work, and so we do monitor the effects.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Well, at the Fed, we are, you know, deeply committed to the mission of CRA, which is for banks to provide credit and other banking services in the communities they serve.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And we have also been of the view for some time that with the evolution of technology particularly and changes—changes in the nature of banking, that it’s an appropriate time—it’s past an appropriate time, but now it’s certainly an appropriate time to revisit the way we think about CRA.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: But we don’t want to lose that focus on community, and, you know, we definitely want to see that fundamental purpose of the law sustained.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Many of the issues that we had were reflected in the OCC’s ANPR, and we’re—we’re hopeful that, over time, there will be a joint proposed rulemaking with the OCC, the FDIC, and the Fed.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: It’s a process, and, you know, we’re very much interested in continuing to push it forward.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So, in principle, the—these starred variables—the long-run growth rate of the economy, the neutral rate of interest, the natural rate of unemployment—don’t move quickly.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: They move very gradually.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: They’re pinned down by longer-run forces, like demographics.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: In the case of the funds rate, it’s more—it’s productivity—it’s appetite for safe assets and demographics and other things, too.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So they move quite slowly through time.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I think we all look at them—those of us who file SEPs every quarter will look at that every quarter and not make a change every quarter but, every now and again, make a change.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And you’re right—we actually—the median ticked up a tenth.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: It’s a tenth we’re talking about here, so—but still, I think it’s a positive thing that people could be raising their estimates of the longer-run neutral rate and potentially the longer-run growth rate.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And maybe reducing their level of the natural rate of unemployment, which has been the trend.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: It’s just that you change those estimates over time.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: They’re informed by incoming data.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: They don’t change a lot, though, although they did—it’s interesting that the neutral rate changed quite sharply after the financial crisis in many different models, and it’s been slow to recover.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I don’t expect a dramatic recovery there, but, you know, we—we’re so bad at forecasting productivity.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: It’s just very hard to know when productivity is going to arrive and in what quantity.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So I think we have to be humble about how little we really know about where these starred value variables either are or are going.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Sure.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: A slowing down in job growth would be an indicator, you know.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: An unexpectedly sharp increase in wages or inflation could tell you that you’re reaching those points.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You know, if headline growth slowed down, that’s another one.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So all of those things would be worth taking into consideration.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I think also, though, we’ve seen sometimes sharp tightening in financial conditions, as we saw at the beginning of 2016, can have a substantial effect pretty quickly on our economy if it’s a broad and significant tightening.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So we would be looking for those kinds of things and many other things.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So, in terms of divergence, yes.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So the U.S. economy is, as I mentioned, is strong and is at a pretty positive moment, you know, with strong growth, healthy labor market, inflation right on target, as I mentioned.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So—and we’ve seen growth abroad, but growth, I think, both in advanced economies and in some emerging economies has slowed down a little bit.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And in that world, you know, if the U.S. is stronger, then that’s just part of the context, part of the environment that could mean a higher dollar.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: It could be—it could therefore mean that some of our demand will wind up being shared with other economies.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: That’s the way the integrated international economy works.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So you could see that, and, you know, it’s just—it’s just all of the—all things that go into thinking about, you know, the path of the economy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I would say, you know, we’re not responsible for the dollar.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Of course, the Treasury is responsible for managing the dollar, but the dollar has only partly recovered the decline that it had in 2017.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: It’s moved up off its lows, but it’s not as high as it was at the beginning of last year yet by a significant margin.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So we’ve said that we would use our tools to assure that the federal funds rate trains—trades within the target range.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And the principal tools we use have been interest on excess reserves and then, at the bottom end, a reverse repo facility.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So we—in June, when we raised rates, we only raised the interest on excess reserves by 20 basis points and raised the range by 25, and that moved federal funds sort of back into the range.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: It worked, and it was successful.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: The federal funds rate traded in the low 190s, well within the range.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We may—we may do that again.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You know, we—again, we have our tools, and we will use them.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We think it’s principally a function just of a number of things, but particularly high Treasury supply, and—which is showing up in repo rates and then showing up in fed funds as well.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So we don’t see it as a—as a big problem.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We see it as a problem we can address with our tools, and we’ll use them if we have to.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So I wouldn’t comment on a CEA paper, and I would imagine they probably wouldn’t comment on our stuff, either, but I would just say this.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So I am familiar with the question and the work.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You know, we look—we look at a range of indicators of wages, and I think the broader, the better.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You really—in a perfect—a perfect wage measure would also include benefits, because a lot of compensation these days shows up in the form of benefits rather than wages, so I think it’s right to choose those broader ones.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: But they’re kind of all telling the same story right now.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Clustered around 3 percent.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: That’s a full percentage point higher than it was five years ago.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: That’s a good thing.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You know, if you’re—if you’re looking for real wage increases, you’ve got to ask inflation, and there, you have to pick an inflation measure.

sentence: We, of course, pick personal consumption expenditures because we think it’s a little better measure.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And that—the trend there is running around 2 percent, so if wages are running at rough—wages and benefits running at roughly 3 percent and inflation running at around 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: PCE core is at about 2, and I think we see that, you know, the temporary increase in headline inflation as being a function of oil prices probably, and we expect inflation to go back down to 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So we think of that as 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: That’s how we think about it.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Is that—I hope that helps.

sentence: So it doesn’t really come up.

sentence: And we do—we do monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We regulate financial institutions, financial stability, that sort of thing.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We don’t have responsibility for fiscal policy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: But in the longer-run, fiscal policy will have a significant effect on the economy, so for that reason, I think my predecessors have commented on fiscal policy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: But they’ve commented on—at a high level rather than trying to get involved in particular, you know, particular measures.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And so—and I—my plan is to kind of stick to the same approach and stay in our lane.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And, you know—so I would just say, it’s—it’s no secret, it’s been true for a long time that with our uniquely expensive health-care delivery system and the aging of our population, we’ve been on an unsustainable fiscal path for a long time, and there’s no hiding from it.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: In the end, we will have to face that, and I think, you know, the sooner, the better.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And also, these are good times.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: These are, you know, this is—this is the economy at nearly full employment or in the range—in the neighborhood of full employment.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Interest rates are low.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: It’s a—it’s a good time to be addressing these things.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So I just—I put that out there and leave it at that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Oh, to stop.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Well, we serve a domestic mandate, which is assigned to us by Congress, and that is to have maximum employment and stable prices.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: About half of global GDP is outside the United States, and way more than half of the growth is outside the United States and in emerging markets, I should say.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And so the performance in the emerging market economies really, really matters to us in carrying out our domestic mandate.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I’d also say that, you know, a strong U.S. economy, where Americans are buying things and the economy is growing and our—you know, that’s going to support demand all around the globe, so that’s a good thing.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Now, we do understand, though, that when we—when our economy is strong and we’re raising rates, that puts upward pressure on interest rates around the world and can affect countries, particularly countries that have significant external dollar borrowing.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And what we try to do is be very transparent about what we’re doing and why.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And we have been, I believe, and we’ve also moved quite gradually.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So I—you know, I think we’ve been performing well on that front.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: There are some countries that are—that are undergoing severe stress, a handful of them, and—but not most emerging market countries.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: It’s a relatively small number, and those particular countries have, you know, have particular vulnerabilities, which are well known in the form of budget deficits, and significant external dollar borrowings, and high inflation, and things like that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So, again, we’ll continue to conduct U.S. monetary policy as transparently as we September 26, 2018 possibly can, and that’s really the best thing we can do, along with supporting U.S. growth.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I’ll Chairman Powell’s Press Conference FINAL just—I think that answers both your questions, actually.

sentence: So I don’t comment on the appropriateness of the level of stock prices.

sentence: I can say that by some valuation measures, they’re in the upper range of their historical value ranges.

sentence: But, you know, I wouldn’t want to—I wouldn’t want to speculate about what the consequences of a market correction should be.

sentence: So that’s a really serious matter when you have a housing bubble and highly levered consumers and housing values fall.
